article.title: Strong Clustering of Lyman Break Galaxies around Luminous Quasars at z 4

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using narrow band (NB) filters over broad bands when selecting Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs) for clustering studies around QSOs?
choices: NB filters are more sensitive to faint galaxies.
NB filters can select LBGs in a much narrower redshift range, reducing line-of-sight projection effects.
NB filters can better distinguish between LBGs and low-redshift interlopers.
NB filters allow for more precise photometric measurements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the long tail towards large negative equivalent widths (EWLyα) in the LBG EWLyα probability distribution represent?
choices: Galaxies with very low star formation rates.
Galaxies with strong Lyα emission, such as Lyman Alpha Emitters (LAEs).
Galaxies with strong Lyman limit breaks.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main challenge in selecting LBGs at z = 3.78 using the novel NB filter system, as shown in the color-color diagram?
choices: The LBGs at z = 3.78 are too faint to be reliably detected in the NB filters.
The color locus of z = 3.78 LBGs overlaps significantly with the colors of low-redshift galaxies, making contamination a concern.
The EWLyα distribution of LBGs at z = 3.78 is too broad to be effectively targeted by the NB filters.
The IGM transmission at z = 3.78 strongly attenuates the Lyα emission line, making it difficult to identify LBGs.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the agreement between the observed QSO-LBG cross-correlation function (filled circles) and the expected value based on the auto-correlation functions of LBGs and QSOs (dashed line) suggest?
choices: Luminous QSOs at z ∼ 4 reside in regions with an enhanced number density of LBGs, consistent with linear bias on large scales.
The clustering of LBGs around QSOs is much weaker than expected, suggesting that QSOs do not reside in massive dark matter halos.
The NB filter technique is not effective at identifying LBGs associated with QSOs, resulting in a weak cross-correlation signal.
The sample of LBGs is heavily contaminated by low-redshift interlopers, diluting the true cross-correlation function.
